awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Infection Multiplicity and Virus Evolution, from Experiments to Large Scale Multi-Population Stochastic Computations
awd_abstract_narration:
To understand how organisms evolve with time requires the development of predictive mathematical descriptions of evolutionary theories along with experimental studies to test these predictions. Because incremental and inheritable genetic changes happen over multiple generations evolutionary theory is difficult to study. Viruses obey the same basic evolutionary rules as higher organisms, but replicate and evolve much faster. Therefore they provide a near-ideal model system for the  test of evolutionary and selection theories. Viruses are also capable of social interactions which can change their evolutionary behaviors. Social interactions arise by a process called co-infection, whereby multiple virus genomes infect and replicate in a single cell, and can result in a number of poorly understood interactions. The research team will perform a series of integrated experimental and mathematical analyses aimed at providing insights into these complex processes.  This research also has significance to other epidemiological situations in which co-infection patterns are observed when different pathogen species simultaneously infect the same host and impact each others' ability to spread. Thus the novel numerical techniques being developed have relevance and significance in more general health areas including cancer studies. 

RNA viruses are characterized by a high mutation rate, allowing them to rapidly diversify and readily adapt to environmental challenges. They provide, therefore, a near-ideal model system for the testing of evolutionary and selection theories that are difficult to approach in more complex organisms. Typically, virus genomes are considered as isolated entities, however, multiple infection (coinfection) of cells is a common occurrence and results in a series of poorly understood social interactions that have the power to shape evolutionary trajectories. A highly tractable experimental system for assessing the model is replication of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV-1) in vitro. HIV-1 multiple infection is promoted by cell-to-cell contact and the formation of virological synapses, in which multiple viruses are simultaneously transferred from one cell to another. In contrast, spread via the release of free virus particles promotes single infection. The relative occurrence of synaptic and free virus transmission, and hence infection multiplicity, can be elegantly manipulated with innovative experimental techniques. Several experimental techniques will be used to generate data on virus growth and virus evolution at different infection multiplicities. Transmission pathways (synaptic and free virus) will be manipulated to change infection multiplicity during virus spread. Evolutionary dynamics will be explored in the context of different mutant types that undergo a variety of social interactions. New techniques will be introduced in order to manipulate the relative importance of cell-free and synaptic transmission, and thus infection multiplicity. Novel computational algorithms will be developed in order to fully understand how multiple infection and social interactions impact the dynamics.  Mathematical models will be tested, parameterized, and employed to explore the evolutionary dynamics at large population sizes. This research will provide greater insights on the relative significance of mechanisms that impact evolution of organisms.

por.por_cntn:
Viruses multiply by entering cells inside an infected organism and by using the cell’s metabolic machinery to produce offspring viruses. During this spread, mutants can be generated, contributing to the evolution of the virus population. The focus of this project was the role of virus social interactions in virus spread and evolution. These social interactions occur when two or more genetically different virus strains infect the same cell (a process called co-infection or multiple infection). Different viruses can help or complement each other if a better replicating virus enhances the spread of an inferior strain. On the other hand, interference can occur, where the advantage of one virus strain is reduced by the presence of another. Finally, different virus strains in a given cell can exchange genetic material, a process called recombination.  Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is an example where such social interactions occur. The aim of our work was to quantify how such social interactions affect the ability of the virus to evolve, using HIV as an experimental model system. To do so, we performed experiments where the level of multiple infection, and hence the prevalence of the social interactions, was varied. HIV spreads by two mechanisms: (i) during transmission via release of free virus, cells typically become infected with only one virus, leading to the absence of social interactions. (ii) during direct cell-to-cell transmission (through the formation of virological synapses), multiple viruses are transferred simultaneously from one cell to another, thus promoting multiple infection and hence the occurrence of social interactions. By placing cultures on a shaking platform, it is possible to experimentally disrupt cell-to-cell transmission, and hence to prevent the occurrence of social interactions. Such experiments can help us experimentally document virus spread and virus evolution in the presence and absence of social interactions. Mathematical models of these dynamics were constructed, and applied to the experimental data to estimate parameters. The mathematical model was then used to fully explore how multiple infection affects viral evolution, especially recombination.

We found that cell-to-cell transmission, and hence multiple infection, significantly accelerated the emergence of recombinant viruses, and hence accelerated the rate of viral evolution. Further mathematical modeling also suggested that cell-to-cell transmission can allow and enhance the spread of a disadvantageous mutant, through the occurrence of viral complementation, where the Darwinian fitness of the disadvantageous mutant is increased by the unmutated virus in coinfected cells. This again points to the role of direct cell-to-cell transmission, and hence of multiple infection, for increasing viral diversity and the rate of viral evolution.

            An important challenge, which has previously held back such research, is that evolving virus populations grow to large sizes, often too large for computer simulations to complete within a feasible amount of time. Evolutionary computational models need to be stochastic in nature because mutants initially exist as small populations, but stochastic simulations become very time-consuming once the population has reached relatively large sizes. Therefore, the development of new computational methods was required to overcome this obstacle. We developed a so called stochastic-deterministic hybrid simulation, where small sub-populations of the virus (such as a minority of mutant-infected cells or multiply infected cells) are simulated stochastically, while the larger wild-type population is at the same time simulated deterministically. We found that such a hybrid simulation approximated the true stochastic simulation with good accuracy, while being characterized by a significantly faster run time. This new numerical methodology allowed exploration of the evolutionary dynamics in a computationally efficient and comprehensive way.

Outcomes of this research are broadly important to the field of virus evolution in general, including work on bacteriophages. In addition, this methodology is relevant to epidemiological settings, where different pathogens can simultaneously infect the same host and impact each other’s ability to spread, including Zika or Dengue virus in mosquitoes that are coinfected with the bacterium Wolbachia. Another application of the general methodology is SARS-CoV-2 virus spread, as demonstrated by our work on transmission hot zones and on the role of human behavior in the evolutionary dynamics of the SARS-CoV-2 virus. The novel numerical algorithm also has significance far beyond the virus infections, and can be used to study for example bacterial and cancer evolution, which we have also demonstrated in this work.

A further important goal of this effort was to create a nourishing research and education environment, where graduate and undergraduate minority students can advance their career goals and broaden their research experience. The PI combined her role of the research leader with her broader duty as a Vice-Chair for Inclusive Excellence at the UCI Mathematics Department, to channel support to women and URM students with interest in STEM disciplines. Dozens of graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students were trained and given opportunities for career development; a number of them have received a degree and continued their careers in Mathematical Biology.
